context: Blood samples were taken at the beginning, middle and end of the exposure trial and used to determine CORT levels and antibody responses. 2.1.2 American kestrels In a separate trial, 20 (17 females and 3 males), adult (3–7 years old) American kestrels were obtained from a breeding colony (avian science conservation center, McGill university). The birds were individually identified with fluorescent color and aluminum leg bands and randomly allocated into 2 groups (control and exposed, n=10/group) except for the three males that were allocated to the control group because they were required by another facility after this study. The birds were housed together in an indoor flight room (7m widex5m highx3m long) with controlled ventilation, temperature (21–23°C), and light cycle (12-h. light/dark); the same conditions as used with the quail.
